Description

Adds a note that event pages need to listen to runtime.onStartup to ensure that they run at least once per browser session.

Motivation

To address the documentation update requirements for Bug 1820331 If the background script of an MV3 extension has a browser.action.onClicked() handler, the background script is not executed on startup.

items.content_html:
Description

This is in scope of the PWA docs project: mdn/mdn#280

In this project, we are adding new guides, tutorials, and how-to pages. We also discussed about adding a reference page that would list all of the APIs/methods/manifest members that PWAs can use.

This is exactly what this PR offers. It adds a new page with links to all of the relevant PWA reference docs: manifest members, service worker APIs, other web APIs.

Motivation

This new page should help PWA devs quickly scan through the list of possible features and APIs and jump to other pages to learn more.

Related issues and pull requests

Part of mdn/mdn#280
items.title: New reference page for PWA

items.content_html:
Description

This PR adds the missing documentation for the following:

  • PopStateEvent()
  • PopStateEvent.state

Motivation

openwebdocs/project#153

Additional details

  • I didn't add an example to PopStateEvent() as the web developer usually does not call this constructor.
  • I removed all uses of window.history throughout MDN: modern usage is the plain history global variable. (One is left in the Window interface where it belongs).
  • I added notes indicating that the History API can only be used in the window global scope (the main thread) and not in workers or worklets.
  • I put PopStateEvent inside the History API group.
  • There would be many more rabbit holes to follow (the guides could be vastly improved), but that's outside the project's scope.
  • The flaws listed are non-written pages unrelated to this work that are in pages I only marginally updated.

Related pull request

  • BCD update: mdn/browser-compat-data#19253
items.title: Document PopStateEvent() and PopStateEvent.state

items.content_html:
This updates the Express dev environment setup to suggest using nvm or nvm-windows to setup your node and npm environment. Previously it suggested using installers and package managers.

Why? Well, I wish I knew about package managers when I started, because they make upgrading a lot easier. I think most developers end up using them, and they are really no harder than using installers.

In addition, they make the instructions easier, because less will have to change next time we update versions of node to a new LTS.

Note that I kept the links to info about package managers/installers, so people can still try that.

This is a precursor to updates for async behaviour that have been tested in mdn/express-locallibrary-tutorial#170
items.title: Express Tute: NVM to install node rather than packagers/installers

items.content_html:
Description

It's not explicitly clear that 303 is a temporary redirect. Add clarification in HTTP 303 description to specify that it is a temporary redirect.

Motivation

Multiple status codes often perform the same function, with the only difference between them being that one is temporary and one is permanent. This is often the most important item that people wonder about with redirect status codes; which ones are temporary and which ones are permanent.

This should be information explicitly provided on all redirect status descriptions.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: cleanup: Explicitly clarify that HTTP 303 is a temporary redirect

items.content_html:
FF110 implements the "focus fixup rule" on elements in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1810077.

This was basically a spec clarification to state what happened to the focus and blur/focus events if focus was lost on an element because:

  • A style like hidden was applied to the element, which cannot accept focus.
  • The element was removed.

The spec changes says that the first case focus should be lost by the element and blur event should fire. This is what happened in FF110, which previously held the focus on the ineligible element.
For removal of element from document the focus should move to the body, but blur should not fire.

To fix this I have

  • explained the FF change in the release notes.
  • In the blur element docs I added a note explaining what the spec requires. I think that is a good place because you'll probably only wonder about this in the context of "why didn't I see the blur element in this case".

Other docs work can be tracked in #25496
items.title: FF110 Relnote and Element: blur focus fixup
